A.summary: Your organization works to understand and control risks. You probably understand that risks can be quantified, and understand that some security controls provide an exponentially greater return on investment than others.

B.summary: Your organization investigates risks, but maybe hasn’t done so formally or consistently.

C.summary: Your organization doesn’t seem to investigate risks, and you should start immediately.

A.summary: Your organization is behaving in a “trustworthy” manner. Managing people is the hardest part of any security management program, and you are working to ensure your team is informed and educated, working towards making security a key part of your culture.

B.summary: Training and education is important, but there’s likely room for improvement in your organization. Managing people is the hardest part of any security management program.

C.summary: Your organization needs to invest in training/education ASAP. Managing people is the hardest part of any security management program.

A.summary: Your organization invests in security. You likely place an emphasis on controlling chaos, which is ultimately beneficial for both security as well as achieving business objectives. You likely have specific security metrics, KPIs, use a secure software development lifecycle.

B.summary: Your organization invests somewhat in security. You may see the benefit of controlling chaos, but you’re probably not there just yet.

C.summary: Your organization doesn’t seem to invest in security, and you should start as soon as possible. Every organization has data worth stealing, and a breach might be an existential threat, especially if you go-to-market in the EU or another jurisdiction where data security and privacy is regulated.

A.summary: Security is well aligned to business goals, which is a great place to start. Strong understanding that security can often be used as a high ROI activity. Security is important to internal stakeholders, so important to us.

B.summary: Your organization is beginning to understand that security can be used as an effective lever to achieve business goals, but there’s room for improvement. This is an exciting result, because the most profit opportunity is on the table.

C.summary: It seems there’s a lot of room for improvement in relating security to business goals. Security is a strong lever for growth, and should be seen as a catalyst for profit.
